newsitem.title: USA: Computer Associates, NCR in pact.
newsitem.headline: Computer Associates, NCR in pact.

text.p: Computer Associates International Inc and NCR Corp said they had formed a product licensing pact in which NCR has agreed to license CA's systems management software to run on its computer systems.

NCR, the former computer arm of AT&T Corp, began trading separately this month. NCR sells computer servers used to run the so-called mission-critical operations of large companies, including data warehousing and transaction processing systems.
The systems are popular among retailers and financial service firms.

The deal furthers Computer Associates strategy aimed at making its CA-Unicenter systems management software the dominant standard for managing organizational computer systems running a variety of different computer operating systems.
Computer Associates said Unicenter will be available on NCR's Windows NT operating system in the first quarter of 1997 and for NCR's UNIX-based systems in the second quarter.

The deal could give a boost to Computer Associates where it needs it most -- in Europe, where NCR has a strong presence. NCR derived 31 percent of its roughly $8 billion in 1995 revenues from its Europe, Middle East and Africa region.

In late December, Computer Associates warned its revenues for the third quarter ended December 31 would fall short of Wall Street expectations. It said it expected revenues in the range of $1 to $1.1 billion, below the $1.2 billion consensus.

Computer Associates blamed the shortfall on its European operations, where it said the company's transition to a greater focus on client/server software has had a bumpy reception compared with its business in North America.

In the fall, Computer Associates announced plans to shift its focus to client/server-based products, which account for a third of its revenues, instead of its traditional focus on mainframe software, from which it derives most of the rest.
NCR is based in Dayton, Ohio. Computer Associates is headquartered in Islandia, N.Y.
